passphrase.name: passphrase
passphrase.description:
Specifies a source for your secret passphrase. Lisk Commander will prompt you for input if this option is not set.
	Source must be one of `prompt`, `pass`, `env`, `file` or `stdin`. For `pass`, `env` and `file` a corresponding identifier must also be provided.
	Examples:
	- --passphrase=prompt (default behaviour)
	- --passphrase='pass:my secret passphrase' (should only be used where security is not important)
	- --passphrase=env:SECRET_PASSPHRASE
	- --passphrase=file:/path/to/my/passphrase.txt (takes the first line only)
	- --passphrase=stdin (takes one line only)

passphrase.name: passphrase
passphrase.description:
Specifies a source for your secret passphrase. Lisk Commander will prompt you for input if this option is not set.
	Source must be one of `prompt`, `pass`, `env`, `file` or `stdin`. For `pass`, `env` and `file` a corresponding identifier must also be provided.
	Examples:
	- --passphrase=prompt (default behaviour)
	- --passphrase='pass:my secret passphrase' (should only be used where security is not important)
	- --passphrase=env:SECRET_PASSPHRASE
	- --passphrase=file:/path/to/my/passphrase.txt (takes the first line only)
	- --passphrase=stdin (takes one line only)

message.name: message
message.description:
Specifies a source for providing a message to the command. If a string is provided directly as an argument, this option will be ignored. The message must be provided via an argument or via this option. Sources must be one of `file` or `stdin`. In the case of `file`, a corresponding identifier must also be provided.
	Note: if both secret passphrase and message are passed via stdin, the passphrase must be the first line.
	Examples:
	- --message=file:/path/to/my/message.txt
	- --message=stdin

args.name: senderPublicKey
args.description: Public key of the sender of the message.

message:encrypt.description: Encrypts a message for a given recipient public key using your secret passphrase.

password.name: password
password.description:
Specifies a source for your secret password. Lisk Commander will prompt you for input if this option is not set.
	Source must be one of `prompt`, `pass`, `env`, `file` or `stdin`. For `pass`, `env` and `file` a corresponding identifier must also be provided.
	Examples:
	- --password=prompt (default behaviour)
	- --password=pass:password123 (should only be used where security is not important)
	- --password=env:PASSWORD
	- --password=file:/path/to/my/password.txt (takes the first line only)
	- --password=stdin (takes the first line only)

passphrase.name: passphrase
passphrase.description:
Specifies a source for providing an encrypted passphrase to the command. If a string is provided directly as an argument, this option will be ignored. The encrypted passphrase must be provided via an argument or via this option. Sources must be one of `file` or `stdin`. In the case of `file`, a corresponding identifier must also be provided.

	Note: if both an encrypted passphrase and the password are passed via stdin, the password must be the first line.

	Examples:
		- --passphrase file:/path/to/my/encrypted_passphrase.txt (takes the first line only)
		- --passphrase stdin (takes the first line only)

outputPublicKey.name: outputPublicKey
outputPublicKey.description: Includes the public key in the output. This option is provided for the convenience of node operators.

signature:broadcast.description:
Broadcasts a signature for a transaction from a multisignature account.
	Accepts a stringified JSON signature as an argument, or a signature can be piped from a previous command.
	If piping make sure to quote out the entire command chain to avoid piping-related conflicts in your shell.

transaction:broadcast.description:
Broadcasts a transaction to the network via the node specified in the current config.
	Accepts a stringified JSON transaction as an argument, or a transaction can be piped from a previous command.
	If piping make sure to quote out the entire command chain to avoid piping-related conflicts in your shell.

passphrase.name: passphrase
passphrase.description:
Specifies a source for your secret passphrase. Lisk Commander will prompt you for input if this option is not set.
	Source must be one of `prompt`, `pass`, `env`, `file` or `stdin`. For `pass`, `env` and `file` a corresponding identifier must also be provided.
	Examples:
	- --passphrase=prompt (default behaviour)
	- --passphrase='pass:my secret passphrase' (should only be used where security is not important)
	- --passphrase=env:SECRET_PASSPHRASE

second-passphrase.name: second-passphrase
second-passphrase.description:
Specifies a source for your second secret passphrase. For certain commands a second passphrase is necessary, in which case Lisk Commander will prompt you for it if this option is not set. Otherwise, Lisk Commander will assume you want to use one passphrase only.
	Source must be one of `prompt`, `pass`, `env`, `file` or `stdin`. For `pass`, `env` and `file` a corresponding identifier must also be provided.
	Examples:
	- --second-passphrase=prompt (to force a prompt even when a second passphrase is not always necessary)
	- --second-passphrase='pass:my second secret passphrase' (should only be used where security is not important)
	- --second-passphrase=env:SECOND_SECRET_PASSPHRASE
	- --second-passphrase=file:/path/to/my/secondPassphrase.txt (takes the first line only)
	- --second-passphrase=stdin (takes one line only)

no-signature.name: no-signature
no-signature.description: Creates the transaction without a signature. Your passphrase will therefore not be required.

votes.name: votes
votes.description:
Specifies the public keys for the delegate candidates you want to vote for. Takes either a string of public keys separated by commas, or a path to a file which contains the public keys.
	Examples:
	- --votes=publickey1,publickey2
	- --votes=file:/path/to/my/votes.txt (every public key should be on a new line)

unvotes.name: unvotes
unvotes.description:
Specifies the public keys for the delegate candidates you want to remove your vote from. Takes either a string of public keys separated by commas, or a path to a file which contains the public keys.
	Examples:
	- --unvotes=publickey1,publickey2
	- --unvotes=file:/path/to/my/unvotes.txt (every public key should be on a new line)

transaction:get.description: Gets transaction information from the blockchain.

pretty.name: pretty
pretty.description: Prints JSON in pretty format rather than condensed. Has no effect if the output is set to table. You can change the default behaviour in your config.json file.

state.name: state
state.description:
Get transactions based on a given state. Possible values for the state are 'unsigned' and 'unprocessed'.
	Examples:
	- --state=unsigned
	- --state=unprocessed

sender-id.name: sender-id
sender-id.description:
Get transactions based by sender-id which is sender's lisk address'.
	Examples:
	- --sender-id=12668885769632475474L

limit.name: limit
limit.description: Limits the returned transactions array by specified integer amount. Maximum is 100.

offset.name: offset
offset.description: Offsets the returned transactions array by specified integer amount.

args.description: Comma-separated transaction ID(s) to get information about.

second-public-key.name: second-public-key
second-public-key.description:
Specifies a source for providing a second public key to the command. The second public key must be provided via this option. Sources must be one of `file` or `stdin`. In the case of `file`, a corresponding identifier must also be provided.

	Note: if both transaction and second public key are passed via stdin, the transaction must be the first line.

	Examples:
	- --second-public-key file:/path/to/my/message.txt
	- --second-public-key 790049f919979d5ea42cca7b7aa0812cbae8f0db3ee39c1fe3cef18e25b67951

passphrase.name: passphrase
passphrase.description:
Specifies a source for your secret passphrase. Lisk Commander will prompt you for input if this option is not set.
	Source must be one of `prompt`, `pass`, `env`, `file` or `stdin`. For `pass`, `env` and `file` a corresponding identifier must also be provided.
	Examples:
	- --passphrase=prompt (default behaviour)
	- --passphrase='pass:my secret passphrase' (should only be used where security is not important)
	- --passphrase=env:SECRET_PASSPHRASE
	- --passphrase=file:/path/to/my/passphrase.txt (takes the first line only)
	- --passphrase=stdin (takes one line only)

second-passphrase.name: second-passphrase
second-passphrase.description:
Specifies a source for your second secret passphrase. For certain commands a second passphrase is necessary, in which case Lisk Commander will prompt you for it if this option is not set. Otherwise, Lisk Commander will assume you want to use one passphrase only.
	Source must be one of `prompt`, `pass`, `env`, `file` or `stdin`. For `pass`, `env` and `file` a corresponding identifier must also be provided.
	Examples:
	- --second-passphrase=prompt (to force a prompt even when a second passphrase is not always necessary)
	- --second-passphrase='pass:my second secret passphrase' (should only be used where security is not important)
	- --second-passphrase=env:SECOND_SECRET_PASSPHRASE
	- --second-passphrase=file:/path/to/my/secondPassphrase.txt (takes the first line only)
	- --second-passphrase=stdin (takes one line only)

no-signature.name: no-signature
no-signature.description: Creates the transaction without a signature. Your passphrase will therefore not be required.

args.name: username
args.description: Username to register as a delegate.

transaction:create:multisignature.description:
Creates a transaction which will register the account as a multisignature account if broadcast to the network, using the following arguments:
		1. Number of hours the transaction should remain in the transaction pool before becoming invalid.
		2. Minimum number of signatures required for a transaction from the account to be valid.
		3. Public keys to verify signatures against for the multisignature group.

json.name: json
json.description: Prints output in JSON format. You can change the default behaviour in your config.json file.

pretty.name: pretty
pretty.description: Prints JSON in pretty format rather than condensed. Has no effect if the output is set to table. You can change the default behaviour in your config.json file.

no-signature.description: Creates the transaction without a signature. Your passphrase will therefore not be required.

args.name: lifetime
args.description: Number of hours the transaction should remain in the transaction pool before becoming invalid.

args.name: minimum
args.description: Minimum number of signatures required for a transaction from the account to be valid.

args.name: keysgroup
args.description: Public keys to verify signatures against for the multisignature group.

transaction:create:second-passphrase.description: Creates a transaction which will register a second passphrase for the account if broadcast to the network.

json.description: Prints output in JSON format. You can change the default behaviour in your config.json file.

no-signature.name: no-signature
no-signature.description: Creates the transaction without a signature. Your passphrase will therefore not be required.

data.name: data
data.description:
Optional UTF8 encoded data (maximum of 64 bytes) to include in the transaction asset.
	Examples:
	- --data=customInformation

transaction:create:vote.description: Creates a transaction which will cast votes (or unvotes) for delegate candidates using their public keys if broadcast to the network.

json.name: json
json.description: Prints output in JSON format. You can change the default behaviour in your config.json file.

pretty.name: pretty
pretty.description: Prints JSON in pretty format rather than condensed. Has no effect if the output is set to table. You can change the default behaviour in your config.json file.

passphrase.description:
Specifies a source for your secret passphrase. Lisk Commander will prompt you for input if this option is not set.

no-signature.name: no-signature
no-signature.description: Creates the transaction without a signature. Your passphrase will therefore not be required.

votes.name: votes
votes.description:
Specifies the public keys for the delegate candidates you want to vote for. Takes either a string of public keys separated by commas, or a path to a file which contains the public keys.
	Examples:
	- --votes=publickey1,publickey2
	- --votes=file:/path/to/my/votes.txt (every public key should be on a new line)

unvotes.name: unvotes
unvotes.description:
Specifies the public keys for the delegate candidates you want to remove your vote from. Takes either a string of public keys separated by commas, or a path to a file which contains the public keys.
	Examples:
	- --unvotes=publickey1,publickey2
	- --unvotes=file:/path/to/my/unvotes.txt (every public key should be on a new line)
